Package stkim1.view.geom

Class MTPolygon

java.lang.Object
stkim1.view.geom.MTPolygon
public class MTPolygon extends Object
MTPolygon contains a polygon map made with a group of MTPoint, and can check if a point is contained.
Since:
0.1
Version:
%I%, %G%
Author:
stkim1

  • Constructor Details

    • MTPolygon

      public MTPolygon(Object pid, @NonNull List<MTPoint> vts) throws Exception
      The points in MTPolygon is henceforth called vertices. When a polygon is instantiated with vertices, it becomes a closed polygon, which cannot be further modified. Thus, we check if at least three vertices are provided, and close the spawned polygon if the condition is met.

      polygon id is not enforced as it is an utility, i.e. you can implement an id only if you need to identify or index polygons.

      Parameters:
      pid - a nullable Object as the id of a polygon.
      vts - a list of at least three or more points (vertices).
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the vertices list in the arguments is null.
      InvalidParameterException - if the number of vertices are less than three.
      Exception

    • MTPolygon

      public MTPolygon()
      When a polygon is instantiated without vertices, it is an open polygon, which can be further modified.

  • Method Details

    • setPolygonId

      public void setPolygonId(Object pid)
      A polygon id is to identify which polygon is selected. Id can be set to anything; String, Object, and/or null if you want. Polygon id is not enforced as it is an utility, i.e. you can implement an id only if you need to identify or index polygons.
      Parameters:
      pid - a nullable Object as the id of a polygon.

    • getPolygonId

      public Object getPolygonId()
      A polygon id is to identify which polygon is selected.
      Returns:
      the polygon id

    • addVertex

      public void addVertex(@NonNull MTPoint vertex) throws Exception
      A point in MTPolygon is henceforth called vertex. When a polygon is instantiated without vertices, it is an open polygon, which can take more vertex.
      Parameters:
      vertex - a vertex of MTPoint.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the vertex is null.
      InvalidObjectException - if this polygon is already closed and you are trying to add another vertex.
      Exception

    • addVertices

      public void addVertices(@NonNull MTPoint[] vts) throws Exception
      Points in MTPolygon is called vertices. When a polygon is instantiated without vertices, it is an open polygon, which can take more vertices.
      Parameters:
      vts - a list of vertices in MTPoint.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the vertices is null.
      InvalidObjectException - if this polygon is already closed and you are trying to add more vertices.
      InvalidParameterException - if the vertices list is empty.
      Exception

    • close

      public void close() throws Exception
      An open polygon can be closed only if at least three MTPoint vertices are present in its vertices list. Otherwise, the polygon throws an exception.
      Throws:
      InvalidObjectException - if there is less than three vertices in the vertices list and you are trying to close this polygon.
      Exception

    • isClosed

      public boolean isClosed()
      When a polygon is closed, you cannot add a vertex to it.
      Returns:
      true if this polygon is closed, false otherwise.

    • getVerticesPath

      public android.graphics.Path getVerticesPath()
      The vertices in this polygon can be drawn on the screen in a line with android.graphics.Path for debugging purpose. The polygon line will be closed if this polygon is closed, otherwise the line is open.

      This is expensive function as it spawns android.graphics.Path object. It becomes as much expensive as the number of polygons and vertices increases. Please use it with caution at your discretion.

      Returns:
      android.graphics.Path of vertices

    • isPointInBBox

      public boolean isPointInBBox(@NonNull MTPoint point)
      Tells you if a point is in the bonding box of this polygon. This is to quickly cull unlikely polygons and to speed up pin-pointing exact polygons the point is contained in.
      Parameters:
      point - a point in MTPoint.
      Returns:
      true if the point is in the bounding box of this polygon, otherwise false.

    • isPointInPolygon

      public boolean isPointInPolygon(@NonNull MTPoint point)
      Tells you if a point is in this polygon. Dan Sunday's "Fast Winding Number Algorithm" is implemented to check precisely if the point really is contained in this polygon.
      Parameters:
      point - a point in MTPoint.
      Returns:
      true if the point is contained in this polygon, otherwise false.
